notes.text:
An update for squid is now available for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.

Red Hat Product Security has rated this update as having a security impact of Important. A Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) base score, which gives a detailed severity rating, is available for each vulnerability from the CVE link(s) in the References section.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
Squid is a high-performance proxy caching server for web clients, supporting FTP, Gopher, and HTTP data objects.

Security Fix(es):

* squid: HTTP Request Smuggling could result in cache poisoning (CVE-2020-15810)

* squid: HTTP Request Splitting could result in cache poisoning (CVE-2020-15811)

* squid: Information Disclosure issue in FTP Gateway (CVE-2019-12528)

* squid: Improper input validation issues in HTTP Request processing (CVE-2020-8449)

* squid: Buffer overflow in reverse-proxy configurations (CVE-2020-8450)

* squid: Request smuggling and poisoning attack against the HTTP cache (CVE-2020-15049)

* squid: Improper input validation could result in a DoS (CVE-2020-24606)

For more details about the security issue(s), including the impact, a CVSS score, acknowledgments, and other related information, refer to the CVE page(s) listed in the References section.
notes.title: Details

cwe.name: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor

notes.text: A flaw was found in squid. It allows a crafted FTP server to trigger disclosure of sensitive information from heap memory, such as information associated with other users' sessions or non-Squid processes.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: Information Disclosure issue in FTP Gateway
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing this update, the squid service will be restarted automatically.

As a workaround, it is possible to disable support for FTP. In order to do so, remove the following line from your squid configuration file:
acl Safe_ports 21

Then add the following lines to your squid configuration file:
acl FTP proto FTP
http_access deny FTP

vulnerabilities.title: Information Disclosure issue in FTP Gateway

notes.text: A flaw was found in squid. Due to incorrect input validation, squid can interpret crafted HTTP requests in unexpected ways to access server resources prohibited by earlier security filters.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: Improper input validation issues in HTTP Request processing
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: This only affects deployments acting as reverse proxy with a http_port 'accel' or 'vhost' (squid 2.x and 3.x) or http_port 'accel' configuration (squid 4.x).
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing this update, the squid service will be restarted automatically.

vulnerabilities.title: Improper input validation issues in HTTP Request processing

cwe.name: Improper Restriction of Operations within the Bounds of a Memory Buffer

notes.text: A flaw was found in squid. Due to incorrect buffer management, a remote client can cause a buffer overflow in a Squid instance acting as a reverse proxy.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: Buffer overflow in reverse-proxy configurations
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: Although the squid packages for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6 through 8 are affected, they are compiled with FORTIFY_SOURCE, which in this case limits the impact of the buffer overflow to an application termination. This only affects deployments acting as reverse proxy with a http_port 'accel' or 'vhost' (squid 2.x and 3.x) or http_port 'accel' configuration (squid 4.x).
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing this update, the squid service will be restarted automatically.

cwe.name: Inconsistent Interpretation of HTTP Requests ('HTTP Request/Response Smuggling')

notes.text: A flaw was found in squid. A trusted client is able to perform a request smuggling and poison the HTTP cache contents with crafted HTTP(S) request messages. This attack requires an upstream server to participate in the smuggling and generate the poison response sequence. The highest threat from this vulnerability is to data confidentiality and integrity as well as system availability.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: CVE-2020-15049 squid: Request smuggling and poisoning attack against the HTTP cache
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: This issue has been rated as having moderate security impact, (despite of having a higher CVSS scoring) because the attack requires an upstream server to participate in the smuggling attack and generate the poison response sequence, which is really uncommon because most popular software are not vulnerable to participation in this attack. While the vulnerability does exists in squid, it is not easily exploitable and requires participation of other components on the network.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing this update, the squid service will be restarted automatically.

vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2020-15049 squid: Request smuggling and poisoning attack against the HTTP cache

cwe.name: Inconsistent Interpretation of HTTP Requests ('HTTP Request/Response Smuggling')

notes.text: A flaw was found in squid. Due to incorrect data validation, a HTTP Request Smuggling attack against HTTP and HTTPS traffic is possible leading to cache poisoning. The highest threat from this vulnerability is to data confidentiality and integrity.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: CVE-2020-15810 squid: HTTP Request Smuggling could result in cache poisoning
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing this update, the squid service will be restarted automatically.

Disable the relaxed HTTP parser in `squid.conf`:

```
relaxed_header_parser off
```

vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2020-15810 squid: HTTP Request Smuggling could result in cache poisoning

cwe.name: Inconsistent Interpretation of HTTP Requests ('HTTP Request/Response Smuggling')

notes.text: A flaw was found in squid. Due to incorrect data validation, an HTTP Request Splitting attack against HTTP and HTTPS traffic is possible leading to cache poisoning. The highest threat from this vulnerability is to data confidentiality and integrity.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: CVE-2020-15811 squid: HTTP Request Splitting could result in cache poisoning
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing this update, the squid service will be restarted automatically.

Disable the relaxed HTTP parser in `squid.conf`:

```
relaxed_header_parser off
```

vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2020-15811 squid: HTTP Request Splitting could result in cache poisoning

notes.text: A flaw was found in squid. A denial of service attack is possible due to an improper input validation. The highest threat from this vulnerability is to system availability.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: CVE-2020-24606 squid: Improper input validation could result in a DoS
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing this update, the squid service will be restarted automatically.
Add the no-digest option to all cache_peer lines in squid.conf

vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2020-24606 squid: Improper input validation could result in a DoS
